dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, so, um, November 11th is coming up, and you know what that means, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, so, um, November eleventh is coming up, and you know what that means, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, A! Singles Day, or 11/11 as they're calling it now. It's, like, China's massive online shopping event.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, A! Singles Day, or eleven over eleven as they're calling it now. It's, like, China's massive online shopping event.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinasand the worldsbiggest online shopping event, known as Singles Day, takes place on November 11... now re-branded as 11/11...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, massive is an understatement. I mean, Alibaba started this back in, what, 2009? With just a handful of brands, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, massive is an understatement. I mean, Alibaba started this back in, what, two thousand nine? With just a handful of brands, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Singles Day rose to prominence when Alibaba successfully launched its first shopping festival on that day in 2009; now re-branded as 11/11, the event boasts over 200,000 participating brandsup from 60,000 in 2017 and just 27 in 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! And now, it's like, over 200,000 brands participating. Last year they did, uh, over $30 billion in sales. This year they're expecting almost $37 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And now, it's like, over two hundred thousand brands participating. Last year they did, uh, over thirty billion dollars in sales. This year they're expecting almost thirty seven billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the event boasts over 200,000 participating brands... It has become by far and away the largest shopping event in the world, raking in just over $30 billion in gross merchandise volume last yearand sales are expected to hit $37 billion by that same metric this year, according to Forrester Forecasts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Thirty-seven billion? Wow. And they're really leaning into the whole spectacle this year, too. I saw Taylor Swift is headlining the opening gala.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Thirty-seven billion? Wow. And they're really leaning into the whole spectacle this year, too. I saw Taylor Swift is headlining the opening gala.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taylor Swift is set to perform as the headliner in the opening gala this year...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, Taylor Swift! And Kim K did a livestream for her fragrances. It's becoming this huge, like, global entertainment event, not just shopping.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Taylor Swift! And Kim K did a livestream for her fragrances. It's becoming this huge, like, global entertainment event, not just shopping.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...while Kim Kardashian did a livestream on Tmall to launch her fragrances for the shopping festival.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And, um, a quarter of US retailers are apparently getting involved this year, too. Apple, Estee Lauder...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And, um, a quarter of U S retailers are apparently getting involved this year, too. Apple, Estee Lauder...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A larger number of U.S. retailersalmost 25%, according to Adobe, plan to get involved, including big names ranging from Apple to Estee Lauder, posting deals on Alibabas platforms as well as their own U.S. websites.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but wait, the article also mentioned something a bit worrying for them, didn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but wait, the article also mentioned something a bit worrying for them, didn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right. The, uh, the survey about Chinese shoppers planning to boycott American goods. Like, 80% of them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right. The, uh, the survey about Chinese shoppers planning to boycott American goods. Like, eighty percent of them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Almost 80% of Chinese shoppers said that they plan to boycott American goods during Singles Day, according to a recent survey from AlixPartners...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Eighty percent? That's, like, a huge chunk of potential customers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eighty percent? That's, like, a huge chunk of potential customers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because of the whole trade war situation. That's gotta sting for those US brands hoping to cash in on this 'SuperBowl for brands' as one Alibaba exec called it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because of the whole trade war situation. That's gotta sting for those U S brands hoping to cash in on this SuperBowl for brands as one Alibaba exec called it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crucial quote: Think of 11/11 as the SuperBowl for brands, Jiang Fan, president of Alibabas Taobao and Tmall businesses, told CNBC. What to watch for: Almost 80% of Chinese shoppers said that they plan to boycott American goods during Singles Day, according to a recent survey from AlixPartners, which predicts the U.S.-China trade war taking a toll on participating U.S. brands this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oof. Talk about a potential mixed bag for them. Still, the sheer scale of 11/11, even with that, is just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof. Talk about a potential mixed bag for them. Still, the sheer scale of eleven over eleven, even with that, is just wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. World's biggest shopping event, hands down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. World's biggest shopping event, hands down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has become by far and away the largest shopping event in the world...
